p: P. marginatum leaves and stems are used in Brazil, especially in Para√≠ba State, against snake bites and as a sedative [ 146] while in north-eastern Brazil and in the northern region, especially in the Amazon, P. marginatum is commonly used for the treatment of inflammatory diseases, snake bites, as well as the liver and bile duct diseases [ 87]. In addition, the indigenous communities in Central America, the Antilles, and South America used P. marginatum for gastrointestinal problems [ 147]. Other than that, Almeida et al. [ 44] also reported the uses of P. marginatum as a tonic, carminative, stimulant, diuretic, and sudorific agents against stomach, liver and gall-bladder pain, toothaches, and snake and insect bites while da Silva et al. [ 119] reported P. marginatum to have antispasmodic actions. A preparation made from the leaves of P. marginatum is used in French Guyana to treat malaria while in Trinidad and Tobago, Puerto Rico and Surinam, P. marginatum has been used to treat female disorders and to help during childbirth [ 17]. Furthermore, P. marginatum is also traditionally used in Brazil to treat asthma, erysipela, problems of the urinary system, vesicle and liver diseases, and to control blood pressure [ 17].
